terms.definition: Foundational Community Supports - A Medicaid program providing targeted benefits to assist eligible individuals with complex health needs obtain and maintain stable housing and employment.

Third-Party Administrator - Wellpoint serves as the single TPA contracting with Washington Health Care Authority for the FCS program, facilitating implementation, enhancing quality, supporting providers, and paying claims.
Services that help individuals experiencing homelessness or housing instability live with maximum independence in community-integrated housing while bolstering healthcare engagement.

Services that assist people with disabilities to participate in the competitive labor market, working in a preferred job with support needed to obtain and maintain competitive employment in an integrated work setting.
The billing code used for Supportive Housing services, per diem. Requires at least 60 minutes of services including at least one instance of face-to-face interaction with the enrollee.
Predictive Risk Intelligence System score - A risk stratification tool. A score of 1.5 or above qualifies as a risk factor for FCS eligibility.
Activities of Daily Living - Basic self-care activities. Need for assistance with three or more ADLs or hands-on assistance with one or more ADL meets health needs-based criteria.
Community Support Services - Services supporting individuals with preparing for and transitioning to housing, including direct and collateral services, and maintaining tenancy once housed.
Work performed on behalf of a specific individual, such as external care coordination, housing search, and landlord engagement, even when the individual is not present.
Washington State's Medicaid program, providing healthcare coverage to eligible low-income individuals and families.
Home- and Community-Based Services - Services provided to help Medicaid beneficiaries with complex health needs transition to and maintain community-based housing and employment resources.

As defined by U.S. Housing and Urban Development (HUD), includes individuals who have been continuously homeless for a year or more, or have had at least four episodes of homelessness in the past three years.
The principle ensuring that Supportive Housing tenants can choose where they want to live and cannot be evicted for rejecting services, disenrolling from FCS, or changing providers.
The functional separation of housing elements (rent collection, property maintenance, tenancy enforcement) from service provision, with different staff handling each function.
Activities that help individuals prepare for and transition to housing, including functional needs assessments, budgeting assistance, and help with applications for income sources.
Interactive Voice Response - An automated phone system available 24/7 for FCS Provider and Enrollee Services when live representatives are unavailable.
National Provider Identifier - A unique identification number for healthcare providers. FCS requires a Type 2 organization NPI for contracting.
Tax Identification Number - Required for provider contracting and billing. Changes require a letter with physical signature on letterhead.
The electronic platform used for submitting claims online at Availity.com. Electronic claims payer ID is WLPNT.
Significant events affecting enrollee health or safety that must be reported to Wellpoint on the same business day of occurrence or provider awareness.
Washington State's Medicaid Management Information System where providers can verify enrollee eligibility online at waproviderone.org.
An assessment identifying enrollee preferences related to housing (type, location, roommates, accommodations) and support needs for maintaining community integration.
The right of Supportive Housing tenants with disabilities to receive housing and supportive services in the most integrated settings available in the community.
A daily rate billing method. For FCS, each per diem code requires at least 60 minutes of services including face-to-face interaction.
Direct, in-person contact with an enrollee, required at least once for each per diem billing code submission.
Eligibility requirements including mental health needs, substance use disorder treatment needs, ADL assistance needs, or complex physical health needs.
Conditions that qualify individuals for FCS services, including chronic homelessness, frequent institutional stays, frequent caregiver turnover, or PRISM score â‰¥1.5.
An institutional care facility as defined in WAC 388-97-0001, where frequent or lengthy stays can qualify as a risk factor for FCS eligibility.
Care facilities including enhanced adult residential care or assisted living facilities as defined in WAC 388-110-020, where frequent stays qualify as a risk factor.
A residential home providing care as defined in WAC 388-76-10000, where frequent stays can qualify as a risk factor for FCS eligibility.
Two or more contacts in the past 12 months with specified institutional care settings, qualifying as a risk factor for FCS eligibility.
90 or more consecutive days within an institutional care facility, qualifying as a risk factor for FCS eligibility.
Utilizing three or more different in-home caregiver providers within the last 12 months, qualifying as a risk factor when current placement is inappropriate.
IRS Form W-9 (Request for Taxpayer Identification Number), required for provider contracting and TIN changes with Wellpoint.
The unique identifier assigned to providers enrolled in Washington's Medicaid program, required for FCS contracting.
The formal process for challenging claim denials or payment amounts, requiring specific documentation and following established procedures.
The primary email address for FCS provider communications including contracting, credentialing, TIN changes, and general inquiries.
Housing where tenant leases confer full rights of tenancy, including limitations on landlord entry and the right to challenge eviction in court.
Requirements that Supportive Housing must meet tenants' individual affordability standards to ensure housing stability.
Regular communication between property managers and support service staff to prevent evictions and ensure tenant access to necessary services.
The requirement for actual handwritten signatures on official documents like TIN change letters; stamped signatures are not accepted.
The provision allowing individuals who previously met chronic homelessness criteria but have been housed for up to 60 days to remain eligible for FCS services.
The comprehensive guide containing policies, procedures, and requirements for FCS providers, available online and subject to updates.
Claims that are submitted correctly with all required information and documentation, eligible for standard payment processing timelines.
Transition Assistance Program - Provides funding for one-time expenses to help FCS enrollees transition to stable housing.
